node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text:
In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.title: How covid-19 exposes systemic racism in America

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 09, 2021. May be an image of fire, outdoors and text that says 'News The IPCC delivers its starkest warning about the world's climate'.

node.text:
The world is now living through climate change, not watching it draw near.⁠
⁠
A report released by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) says that climate change is “unequivocally” caused by humans and temperatures may rise more than 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels by 2050, if not sooner.⁠
⁠
The changes are now “affecting every inhabited region across the globe”.⁠
⁠
The report arrives at a time of shattered temperature records and terrifying fires and floods. And the IPCC's models of climate change are, more than ever before, backed up with observations. ⁠
⁠
This makes the science more accurate, but not more reassuring. ⁠
⁠
But there is some good news. To read what it is, and why it offers a call to arms for Glasgow's COP26, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: AP Photo/Michael Pappas

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, fire and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠The tactics used to fight wildfires are much the same the world over, and have changed little in the past several decades.⁠
⁠
Fire crews are busier than ever, yet their toolkit no longer seems sufficient. This year, with months of the fire season left to run, some 3m acres across America have already burned, almost 1m more than in the same period last year.⁠
⁠
Fire suppression is a relatively modern policy but it is one that is increasingly being questioned. Starting controlled fires or selectively letting small wildfires burn might be the right strategy but it can be a hard sell.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why a new approach is in order.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ringo Chiu/ZUMA Wire / eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠The frightening prospect of the Pacific’s sinking islands is well known. It may not entirely be true, but such narratives have their uses.⁠
⁠
What is more concerning, and urgent, are the other effects of climate change. These are more varied and more unpredictable.⁠
⁠
“King tides” are becoming more frequent. The saltwater can kill crops such as banana and papaya and seeps into groundwater.⁠
⁠
“The islands are not drowning,” says one former economic adviser to Kiribati. “But, humans and plants alike, they may well die of thirst.”⁠
⁠
Many islanders have picked up and left. To read why this may become one long­-term solution for Pacific countries, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Jonas Gratzer/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.text:
“I think school closures did not actually seem to protect all people.” ⁠
⁠
On “The Economist Asks” podcast Emily Oster, author of “The Family Firm” and economics professor at Brown University, explains why she fought for schools in America to stay open during the pandemic.⁠
⁠
Another topic for discussion is whether data make better parents.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to hear why crunching the numbers can take the stress out of raising children.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Leaders The global shortage of semiconductors is a mostly self-solving problem'.

node.text:
Would you like chips with that? ⁠
⁠
You’re not the only one. A sudden surge in demand for microchips has led to a shortage of them. ⁠
⁠
That has helped lift the valuations of firms such as Nvidia, whose chips power everything from video-gaming to data centres. But boom time for sellers means misery for buyers. ⁠
⁠
Carmakers, whose products have become computers on wheels, are among the victims. Analysts say the industry might build around 5m fewer cars this year, all for want of their tiniest components. ⁠
⁠
Yet governments should resist any calls for subsidies—chipmaking is a cyclical business which, between the peaks and troughs, has been enjoying strong growth for decades. ⁠
⁠
To learn why policymakers should leave the crisis to solve itself, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg via Getty Images

node.text:
Cells are the basic units of life—but how do they power it? ⁠
⁠
Life is made of cells, and cells from pre-existing cells. The 30 trillion cells of which a human body is composed can in almost every case be traced back to the single fertilised egg which start.⁠
⁠
A cell is not just a set of contents. It is also a set of processes running alongside each other.⁠
⁠
Of all the processes that continue from cell to cell as life goes on, none is more fundamental than those which provide life's energy. In that, membranes and sets of proteins called electron-transport chains are essential.⁠
⁠
You can learn more in the second of six guides to biology that we're publishing. Next week we'll be taking a look at how organs are made.⁠
⁠
But before this, it is useful to know about cells and molecules. Tap the link in our bio to read how the cells, and their chemical reactions, provide the fuel for life.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @danieliev

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and tree.

node.text:
⁠Brought up in Nice and destined for a nine-to-five life, on his 18th birthday Frenchy Cannoli ran away in search of the best hashish ever made. ⁠
⁠
He found it in the Parvati Valley in the foothills of the Himalayas, where the cannabis plants were protected by the beautiful goddess Parvati: charas, or Indian hashish, harvested as humans had probably done since the glimmering dawn of time.⁠
⁠
Savouring each complexity and every moment, he might have been drinking wine. The comparison was new but, to a Frenchman, obvious. Like vines, cannabis plants reflected their terroir.⁠
⁠
To read our obituary for the master of hashish, who died on July 18th, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Taliesin Gilkes-Bower

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 08, 2021. May be a cartoon.

node.text:
There are three types of crypto investors, according to Mohamed El-Erian of Allianz, an insurer and asset manager. Are you one of them?⁠
⁠
“Fundamentalists” believe bitcoin will replace government-issued currencies one day. ⁠
⁠
Meanwhile “tacticians” reckon its value will rise as more people invest in it. ⁠
⁠
And “speculators” want to gamble.⁠
⁠
Too much seems at stake for bitcoin to crash all the way to zero—but what if it did? To read how a thought experiment helps uncover the links between crypto and mainstream finance, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @kaltoons1

node.text:
It was once hoped that the internet would be a force for openness and freedom. It was not to be. ⁠
⁠
Bad information often drove out good. Authoritarian states co-opted the technologies that were supposed to loosen their grip. Information was wielded as a weapon of war. ⁠
⁠
Amid this disappointment one development offers cause for fresh hope: the emerging era of open-source intelligence. ⁠
⁠
The emancipation of information promises to have profound effects—and can humble some of the world's most powerful countries. ⁠
⁠
To read how open-source intelligence will make the world less mysterious and a little less dangerous, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Cover: @markalexlong

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be a cartoon of 2 people and text that says 'WHY SATAN SHOULD CHAIR YOUR MEETINGS'.

node.text:
Which character from literature would you be in an office meeting? ⁠
⁠
On any given weekday some 50m meetings are held in American workplaces alone. The average executive now spends 23 hours in them each week, a figure that has more than doubled since the 1960s. ⁠
⁠
People have been gathering to discuss decisions since Adam and Eve huddled over the forbidden fruit. The Western canon is ripe with unharvested wisdom on how to make meetings more productive. ⁠
⁠
Word of advice from @1843mag, don't be a Ralph or an Agamemnon. Play the devil instead. Tap the link in our bio to read a literature lover’s guide to office politics.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Pierlugi Longo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business The tycoon who controls ports, power stations, solar farms and airports'.

node.text:
Long before the hoodie was invented, pioneers of business preferred to call themselves self-made men rather than entrepreneurs.⁠
⁠
Gautam Adani is one of those people.⁠
⁠
He started his career haggling for diamonds, and now controls more ports, power stations, solar farms and airports than almost any other private tycoon.⁠
⁠
Mr Adani is a champion of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s drive for self-reliance, he courts environmental, social and governance funds from around the world.⁠
⁠
But Adani Group’s hunger for capital creates a conundrum as it increasingly peddles its clean-energy businesses. Tap the link in our bio to find out why. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @brett.ryder.illustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and people standing.

node.text:
⁠Is Evo Morales staging a comeback in Bolivia?⁠
⁠
In 2019 signs of fraud in an election apparently won by the leftist president, Evo Morales, led to weeks of protests. After the police and army withdrew their support, Mr Morales resigned and fled to Mexico.⁠
⁠
Following Luis Arce’s election, Evo Morales returned to Bolivia late last year, and appears to be keen to get back into politics.⁠
⁠
The opposition argues that the origins of the uprising and the rupture of democracy lay not in 2019 but in 2016, when Evo Morales ignored constitutional term limits.⁠
⁠
But many people no longer care whether what occurred in 2019 was fraud or a coup. To find out why the need for jobs, vaccines and food is a more pressing concern, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Gaston Brito/Getty Images
